title: 103_hr4759
content: The Act may be cited as the "Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Act of 1994". The Congress recognizes the Department of Energy's contributions to math and science education, the need for collaboration between agencies and educators, the importance of outstanding teachers in the education community, and the effectiveness of pilot programs. Elementary and secondary school math and science teachers play a crucial role in effective education programs. A pilot program has shown the effectiveness of exceptional teachers serving in professional staff roles in the Senate and House of Representatives. The Act establishes a national fellowship program for outstanding math and science teachers, known as "Albert Einstein Fellows". The Act defines key terms such as "contractor" as a nonprofit educational organization selected by the Secretary, "Secretary" as the Secretary of Energy, "elementary school" and "local educational agency" as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, and "outstanding" as a teacher who is a winner of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching. A qualified elementary or secondary school mathematics or science teacher must be a State or national winner of the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics and Science Teaching, have participated in the Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program, or received comparable national or State recognition. They must also have taken a sabbatical leave to participate in a fellowship program under the Act, with a guarantee of returning to their teaching position. The Act allows qualified teachers to take sabbatical leave for fellowship programs and guarantees their return to teaching positions in the same school district. The term "secondary school" is defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. SEC. 5. FELLOWSHIP PROGRAM AUTHORIZED. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program authorizes the Secretary to provide 10 outstanding math or science teachers with fellowships each fiscal year. The number of fellowships awarded may be reduced if the appropriated amount is less than authorized. Priority is given to awarding fellowships in such cases. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program authorizes the Secretary to provide fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers each fiscal year. The number of fellowships may be reduced if the appropriated amount is less than authorized, with priority given to specific individuals. The Secretary shall provide fellowships to teachers in various government departments. The Albert Einstein Distinguished Educator Fellowship Program authorizes the Secretary to provide fellowships to outstanding math or science teachers in various government departments for a 10-month period coinciding with the academic year. The Secretary may enter into a contract with a contractor for program administration. The Secretary can award fellowships for 10 months aligning with the academic year. A contractor may be hired for program administration, including developing an application process and inviting teachers from recognized programs to apply. The development and administration of an initial screening process for the Albert Einstein Fellowship Program to select outstanding teachers from recognized programs. Orientation program development for selected fellowship recipients. The responsibilities include final selection of fellowship recipients, orientation program development, establishment of reporting and evaluation program, submission of annual reports to the Secretary, and administration of all funds received under the Act. The contractor is responsible for selecting fellowship recipients, developing orientation programs, reporting to the Secretary, and administering funds received under the Act. Funds can only be used for recipient salaries, insurance contributions, administrative expenses, and information dissemination. The contractor is responsible for selecting fellowship recipients, developing orientation programs, and administering funds received under the Act. Funds can be used for recipient salaries, insurance contributions, administrative expenses, relocation expenses, and conducting final selection interviews. Additionally, the contractor may seek funding from non-Federal sources for travel and professional meeting expenses. The contractor selects fellowship recipients and administers funds for various expenses, including travel and professional meetings. Final selections are made in Washington, D.C., with involvement from House leaders. The selection process for fellowship recipients involves the Speaker of the House, Minority Leader, Majority Leader of the Senate, and other key officials in assigning recipients to either the House or Senate. The selection process for fellowship recipients involves key officials selecting 1 recipient each to be placed within their department or agency. Recipients will interview in various sections before final placement. The final placement of fellowship recipients involves placing them in various sections, offices, or divisions within the department, agency, institute, or office on or before the first day of the fellowship period. Each fellowship recipient will be paid at a rate not exceeding GS-13 of the General Schedule. $550,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1995, with additional funds for fiscal years 1996 through 2001.
